These Lazy Bats Are Super-Efficient Killers That Carefully Conserve Energy to Attack at a Moment’s Notice
Wild fringe-lipped bats spend just one-tenth of the night in flight, but they can precisely snatch a calling frog and nab prey that rivals their own size
In the pursuit of radio-tagged bats, Leonie Baier has gotten her truck stuck in the mud in the middle of the jungle with no cellphone reception. She has waited patiently outside a cave for an entire night, a beeping signal on her tracking device indicating the creature was close—only to realize the following morning that the flying mammal had been in a different cave nearby. She has waded neck-deep into a flooded underground passage, sometimes diving under root clusters to reach her quarries.
That’s because she must collect the tracking devices glued to the bats if she hopes to recover the precious data contained on them. “I do anything I can to get that logger back,” says Baier, of the Naturalis Biodiversity Center in the Netherlands.
Now, these investigations by Baier and her colleagues have revealed an “entirely surprising” result: The predatory fringe-lipped bats they work so hard to find are much more successful at catching their targets than the researchers are at capturing them. While Baier sometimes struggles to find a bat she knows is tantalizingly close, the animals are highly accurate hunters when they leave their roosts to snag a meal, despite sometimes putting in very little effort.
In a study published recently in Current Biology, the team found fringe-lipped bats have a more than 50 percent success rate in capturing their prey and waste little energy doing it. “The success rate [of fringe-lipped bats] is crazy,” says Teague O’Mara, director of conservation evidence at Bat Conservation International, who was not involved in the research.
Some other predators, like porpoises and dragonflies, achieve success rates above 90 percent by catching abundant, small prey. But the fringe-lipped bats capture prey that’s typically about 7 percent of their body mass—and sometimes nearly as large as the bat itself. This puts them ahead of the likes of leopards, lions and polar bears, which also capture bigger prey but boast success rates of only 20 percent, 14 percent and 2 percent, respectively.
It turns out, the bats’ trick is an unusual survival strategy that lets them work smarter rather than harder. “They have giant ears—they just hang there and listen,” Baier says.
Fringe-lipped bats, named for the bumps around their mouth and nose, are found from southern Mexico down to Brazil and Bolivia. In Panama, they often prey on túngara frogs, amphibians a little smaller than a golf ball with mating calls that are easily pinpointed by the right set of big ears. The bats find these frogs by listening for their vocalizations—meaning that the amphibians’ best efforts to find mates sometimes work against their very survival. “They announce themselves: ‘Hello, I’m dinner, I’m here,’” says Baier.
Much of the research on these frog-eating bats was done in captive settings due to the difficulty of studying them in the wild. “They are fast, they are small, they are on the wing, and it’s nighttime,” says Baier, who was a postdoctoral fellow at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama and Aarhus University in Denmark at the time of research. But because tracking devices are getting ever smaller, Baier and her colleagues saw an opportunity to learn more about how these carnivorous bats find success outside the walls of the lab.
Did you know? Leaf-nosed bats
Fringe-lipped bats belong to the most ecologically diverse bat group: the leaf-nosed bats. These mammals have a spearhead-like structure on the ends of their muzzles that’s known as the nose leaf and is thought to help direct echolocation calls.
The team captured bats in March and October 2023 in Soberanía National Park, near the town of Gamboa, Panama. This part was relatively easy, as they went to known sites with larger roosts. They caught around 100 bats.
They then fitted each bat with a small radio-tracking device, an accelerometer, a magnetometer and an ultrasonic microphone that could record things such as echolocation and chewing. The whole getup was about the size of a gummy bear. They affixed these to the bats’ back fur using a skin glue that dissolves after a couple of days.
Between one and five days later, Baier and her colleagues went back to the same area where they caught the bats, and they homed in on the trackers using radio-telemetry devices. Given the difficulty of finding a tagged bat, the team got back workable data from only about 20 of the devices. The rest either didn’t work, or the researchers couldn’t find the bat again. “It’s difficult, but to me it’s also the most fun part,” says Baier.
Once the bats were caught, the researchers removed the trackers; they also weighed and measured the bats, took fecal and hair samples, and counted parasites.
“What we found mostly was that they don’t do much—that was the most astonishing for me,” Baier says. They spent only about 11 percent of their time flying. The rest was sleeping, eating or waiting, perched on tree branches or other structures, listening for prey.
“It’s pretty incredible insight about a bat,” says O’Mara.
Listening to the recordings, Baier could visualize what the bats were doing when the action did kick off. She’d hear a chorus of frog calls nearby and sometimes the echolocation of other bats, then the subject would take wing—motion confirmed by the accelerometer and magnetometer.
“All of a sudden, you can hear one frog getting really, really loud, then it goes quiet,” Baier says. More flying ensued, then the clear sound of a bat diving into a lip-smacking meal. Baier likes to mimic the chewing noise.
It wasn’t always small frogs. In one case, Baier was straining to listen to low-volume sounds on the recording. Then, she says, “my ears almost exploded”—whatever this bat had caught was putting up a real fight, and loudly. She found several more of these cases, with what sounded like larger prey. The struggle usually ended with a crunch. Baier assumes it was the bat biting into its prey’s skull.
Baier’s team used the length of a bat’s chewing to estimate the size of its prey. In one case, the bat ate for nearly half an hour—much longer than the average eight minutes it takes to consume a túngara frog. Accelerometers showed the bat likely fell asleep after starting the meal, then woke up and began to chew again without leaving its perch. “These bats don’t even let go when they fall asleep,” Baier says.
The cycle happened several more times—it took the bat 84 minutes of eating time spread throughout half the night to finish with this food. Follow-up experiments revealed that whatever the creature was—fringe-lipped bats also prey on lizards, hummingbirds and even other bats—it was nearly as big as the predator itself. The largest prey caught by the bats ranged from 17 to 30 grams.
But most often, the bats consumed prey of about 1.7 grams, which roughly aligns with the size of a túngara frog.
While bats did sit around eavesdropping for frogs, they also hunted more actively. Just over half of their attacks were launched from flight rather than from a perch. They seemed to hunt chirping frogs more from the air, possibly since the amphibians’ loud calls can be more easily heard over the noisy atmosphere of flying, the researchers suggest. While perched, the bats were more likely to attack non-vocalizing prey, perhaps because it’s easier to listen to subtler noises for a bat that sits still.
Overall, the bats were extremely successful when they went on the chase. Though they made a kill about half the time on average, some individuals were much more talented. “I was very proud of my bats,” Baier says. “They were so good.”
What sets the bats apart is not only their success, but also their efficiency. Some large carnivores have higher success rates—African wild dogs, for example—but most spend a lot more energy to find and kill their prey across wide geographic ranges. These bigger animals can store lots of energy in their bodies, allowing for high-intensity pursuits or days-long bouts of stalking that might only rarely end with a kill. Fringe-lipped bats, meanwhile, don’t travel very far from their roosts to hunt. As small-bodied animals, the bats must survive by burning their limited fat reserves until they catch their first meal of the night. Precision is paramount. “We are thinking this only works because they have so much prey around,” Baier says.
But she’s concerned that many of the forest habitats around wetlands suitable for túngara frogs are disappearing. If humans encroach on too many of these wetlands, or other factors like disease or climate change take a toll on frog populations, it may not be so easy for fringe-lipped bats to catch a meal. “Their whole strategy won’t work anymore,” Baier says.
O’Mara says that many bats live at the edge of their metabolic ceiling—their limit for energy expenditure—so their ability to thrive in the wild depends on abundant prey. “It’s incredibly important to protect those kinds of forest.”

An Asteroid Might Slam Into the Moon in 2032—and Create a Fiery Flash That’s Visible to Earthlings, New Research Suggests
Currently, NASA estimates that asteroid 2024 YR4 has a 4.3 percent chance of hitting our lunar companion
Early last year, asteroid 2024 YR4 caught the public’s attention as its chances of hitting Earth in the near future climbed to 3.1 percent. It was the highest probability of a strike by an object of its size, roughly 200 feet wide, or larger ever recorded by NASA. But the chances quickly dropped to near zero, as experts had predicted.
Now, a less dangerous but still interesting scenario is developing. While the Earth is in the clear, the moon might be in 2024 YR4’s line of fire on December 22, 2032. NASA’s most recent update places the asteroid’s chance of hitting our lunar neighbor at 4.3 percent. The European Space Agency (ESA) deems it to be 4 percent, per a statement.
What’s more, the impact might create a minutes-long fiery flash that earthlings could see, as well as a powerful lunar quake detectable by equipment on the moon, according to a study posted January 15 to the preprint server arXiv. The work has not been peer-reviewed.
“It is a very rare event for an asteroid this large to impact the moon—and it is rarer still that we know about it in advance. The impact would likely be visible from Earth, and so scientists will be very excited by the prospect of observing and analyzing it,” ESA astrophysicist Richard Moissl says in the agency’s statement.
The situation is “a rare ‘natural experiment’: a forecastable small-body impact whose signatures could be scientifically rich and operationally relevant,” writes study co-author Yifei Jiao, a planetary scientist at the University of California, Santa Cruz, and Tsinghua University in China, in an email to Live Science’s Deepa Jain.
Based on researchers’ current knowledge, asteroid 2024 YR4 might hit the moon at a speed of nearly 9 miles per second, which would result in a roughly 0.6-mile-wide crater about 500 feet deep. So, Jiao and his colleagues ran computer simulations to predict where the object could possibly land and other characteristics of the crash.
Their analyses hint that the strike would happen around 10:19 A.M. Eastern Standard Time in the moon’s southern region, and it would create a minutes-long burst of light between magnitudes -2.5 and 3. That’s roughly the brightness of Venus at night, reports Live Science, although there’s only a small chance that the strike would happen in an unlit part of the moon, which is the only way it could be seen by the naked eye. After the initial burst, the site should glow in infrared wavelengths—which aren’t visible to human eyes—for hours as the molten rock cools.
The event would also lead to a moonquake of roughly magnitude 5.0 and eject around 1.1 million tons of debris into space, the team found. It would “be the most energetic lunar impact event ever recorded in human history,” the researchers write in the paper.
Need to know: What’s an asteroid?
These space rocks are remnants from the formation of the solar system some 4.6 billion years ago. Most are orbiting the sun in the asteroid belt, which is between Mars and Jupiter.
Additionally, a study published in August 2025 in the Astrophysical Journal Letters investigated how debris scattered from the messy affair might affect satellites. “This could pose a lot of risks to Earth-orbiting assets,” Brent Barbee, a flight dynamics engineer at NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center who was not involved in either study, said at the American Geophysical Union’s annual meeting in December, as reported by Science News’ Nikk Ogasa.
Asteroid 2024 YR4 was first detected on December 27, 2024, by the Asteroid Terrestrial-impact Last Alert System (ATLAS) station in Chile. NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope might catch a glimpse of it this month, which could help researchers refine the odds of it crashing into the moon, per Science News

From Abraham Lincoln’s patent to James A. Garfield’s geometry proof,...
articles.content:
One Was a Teenage Diplomat. Another Was a Nuclear Engineer. Here’s How Eight Presidents Made Their Mark Outside of the White House
From Abraham Lincoln’s patent to James A. Garfield’s geometry proof, learn how these 19th- and 20th-century commanders in chief shaped their legacies beyond politics
In 1876, when James A. Garfield was serving his seventh term in Congress, he devised an original proof for the Pythagorean theorem. A classics scholar who’d taught math, history, philosophy, Greek, Latin and rhetoric at an Ohio college, the 20th president was also a preacher, a Union major general during the Civil War and a lawyer.
Garfield is far from the only former commander in chief to boast an impressive array of accomplishments. Many of the 45 individuals who have served as president of the United States demonstrated leadership in public service or the military before assuming the highest office in the land. Some numbered among the best educated and most talented of their generation.
Most presidential backgrounds conform to a particular mold. Twenty-six presidents passed the bar prior to taking office. Even Andrew Jackson, whose political rival John Quincy Adams called him “a barbarian who could not write a sentence of grammar,” was admitted to the bar. In addition to the Harvard University-educated Adams, 14 other American presidents have obtained Ivy League degrees. Three—Ulysses S. Grant, Dwight D. Eisenhower and Jimmy Carter—attended the country’s prestigious military academies.
But for this list, we’re looking at historic examples of presidents whose achievements went more against type. Some presidential history enthusiasts might rankle at the omission of Thomas Jefferson and Theodore Roosevelt, whose reputations as polymaths are well known. This article highlights 19th- and 20th-century presidents whose academic and intellectual successes might be less familiar to readers.
John Quincy Adams was a teenage diplomat and polyglot.
In 1782, 14-year-old John Quincy Adams wrote to his father, future President John Adams, from St. Petersburg, Russia, where he was serving as the French interpreter for the U.S. envoy. The young Adams was already fluent in the era’s diplomatic language; he’d learned the ropes while accompanying his father on diplomatic missions to France several years prior. Now, Adams reported that he was taking German lessons to expand his foreign language skills.
Adams gained proficiency in reading and translating German but never quite grasped Russian, although he gamely studied it while serving as the U.S. ambassador to Russia in his own right between 1809 and 1814. The sixth commander in chief was the U.S. president most well versed in foreign languages, achieving varying degrees of proficiency in French, Latin, Greek, Dutch, German, Russian and Italian.
“I learned about all things John Quincy through reading through his diaries,” says Neal Millikan, a historian who led the effort to digitize “all 15,000 pages” of the president’s journals. She knows from Adams’ own hand that his Greek and Latin skills weren’t up to par when he arrived at Harvard in 1785. “He said that was because he largely educated himself after a while,” reading Cicero as a teenage diplomat in Europe, Millikan explains. Adams ultimately overcame his language deficiencies and graduated after two years, ranking second in his class.
As president in the 1820s, Adams was an early, vocal proponent of astronomy, mocked when he advocated for America to build “lighthouses of the skies” that would rival European observatories. He gave his last public speech at the cornerstone-laying ceremony for the Cincinnati Observatory, the oldest public observatory in the Western Hemisphere. Throughout his life, Adams also found joy in writing poetry.
William Henry Harrison was the only U.S. president to attend medical school.
William Henry Harrison had the shortest tenure of any American president, dying just 31 days after he delivered a two-hour long inaugural address in the rain, without wearing a coat or a hat. (Historians have long attributed his death to pneumonia, but that diagnosis is debated today.)
Had Harrison completed his medical studies at the University of Pennsylvania, where he trained under Benjamin Rush, America’s founding father of medicine, he perhaps could have heeded the ancient proverb “Physician, heal thyself.” But the young Harrison departed Philadelphia, the nascent nation’s center of medicine, a few months after his father’s death in 1791. His father had left him land but no money for tuition. Instead of pursuing medicine, Harrison joined the military and became a national hero at the 1811 Battle of Tippecanoe. That victory became the centerpiece of his successful 1840 presidential campaign.
James K. Polk overcame childhood illness to become an academic standout.
In 1812, 17-year-old James K. Polk rested fitfully on a makeshift mattress in the back of a covered wagon traveling from Tennessee to Philadelphia. Polk’s father, a prosperous landowner, hoped that Philip Syng Physick, America’s leading surgeon and a protégé of Rush, could remove the urinary stones that had deprived his son of regular schooling and a normal childhood. But Polk was in such great pain that his father diverted the wagon to a surgeon in Kentucky, who gave the boy brandy and successfully removed the stones, although the brutal procedure might have rendered the future president sterile or impotent for life.
With his pain gone, the bright, promising Polk thrived academically. He entered the University of North Carolina as a sophomore in 1816 and graduated at the top of his class in 1818, delivering the Latin commencement address.
As president, Polk achieved “nearly everything that he said he wanted to accomplish … and everything he had promised in his party’s platform,” writes historian John C. Pinheiro in an essay for the Miller Center, a nonpartisan research institution affiliated with the University of Virginia. These campaign goals included the acquisition of vast swaths of new territory and the lowering of tariff rates.
Abraham Lincoln is the only president to hold a patent.
Between 1858 and 1860, Abraham Lincoln delivered multiple lectures across Illinois on the vital importance of “discoveries and inventions” to the progress of mankind. Yet he never told audiences that he was responsible for one such innovation: U.S. Patent No. 6,469, a device for “buoying vessels over shoals.” Lincoln is the only American president to hold a patent.
The idea for the invention arose when Lincoln was serving as a U.S. congressman in 1847. His journey home to Illinois from Washington, D.C. was delayed when another steamer ran aground on a sandbar. Lincoln watched the boat’s captain lash empty casks to the hull to give the vessel enough buoyancy to navigate over the shoals. Lincoln, a former riverboat pilot himself, designed “adjustable buoyant air chambers” that could be attached to the sides of a boat and inflated by bellows to lift it over obstructions. When Lincoln returned to Washington in late 1848 for his final session in Congress, he brought a model of his invention with him, securing a patent for it the following year.
Jason Emerson, author of Lincoln the Inventor, says the 16th president never spoke publicly about the invention. “When he became president, all the journalists, of course, discovered it,” Emerson explains. Back then, the U.S. Patent Office put models of patents on display. Many journalists poked fun at the invention, Emerson says. “They made comments like, ‘Well, as an invention, his … isn’t that great, but maybe he’ll have better luck steering the ship of state.’”
Ulysses S. Grant wrote a literary masterpiece in the final year of his life.
Presidential historian Henry Graff once argued that “the best autobiographical writing by a president was done by Ulysses S. Grant.” In 1884, Grant, who had recently been diagnosed with throat cancer, decided to write a memoir to ensure his family’s financial security after his death. The previous year, an investment banker had swindled Grant out of his life savings. The American writer Mark Twain, a friend of Grant’s, persuaded the celebrated Civil War general to write an account of his life. Twain arranged for the book’s publication, promising Grant 70 percent of the profits.
Grant completed the memoir just days before his death on July 23, 1885. Edmund Wilson, the foremost literary critic of the 20th century, compared the work to Henry David Thoreau’s Walden and Walt Whitman’s Leaves of Grass. Twain called it a “great, unique and unapproachable literary masterpiece.” Although The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn author was by no means an uninterested observer, his praise has been echoed by critics ever since.
The 18th president’s two-volume memoir rivaled sales of Uncle Tom’s Cabin, ultimately netting the Grant family $450,000 (around $15.5 million today). The first $200,000 royalty check (around $6.9 million today) that Twain delivered to Grant’s widow in 1886 set a publishing record for the era.
James A. Garfield devised a proof for the Pythagorean theorem.
The New England Journal of Education published Garfield’s original proof for the Pythagorean theorem on April 1, 1876. As William Dunham, a historian of mathematics at Santa Clara University, says, the proof—a step-by-step argument proving a mathematical statement—was “both clever and sound.” Garfield proved the theorem, which explains the relationship between three sides of a right triangle, by constructing a trapezoid from two identical right triangles and computing its area in two ways. Dunham notes that Garfield’s trapezoid is essentially a “bisected” version of an ancient Chinese proof built on nested squares.
In a March 7, 1876, diary entry, Garfield wrote that he’d shared his solution with a mathematician at Dartmouth College, “who said it was new” and arranged for its publication. A different mathematician, Elisha Scott Loomis, included Garfield’s work in his 1940 book, The Pythagorean Proposition, a compendium of 370 distinct proofs stretching back to antiquity.
Garfield’s Pythagorean proof offers just a glimpse into the brilliance of America’s 20th president, who was shot by a disgruntled lawyer in July 1881, just four months into his term. The 2025 Netflix mini-series “Death by Lightning,” which stars Michael Shannon as Garfield, has helped familiarize more Americans with the president’s political ascent and untimely death, but few know about his life prior to his election.
In addition to the aforementioned intellectual achievements, Garfield argued several cases before the Supreme Court while serving as a congressman. He was preparing for a Supreme Court oral argument when he published his Pythagorean proof.
Did you know? The death of President James A. Garfield
- Garfield survived for 80 days following his shooting, dying on September 19, 1881, at age 49.
- An autopsy found that the president died from septic blood poisoning and complications stemming from the shooting. The bullet fired by his assassin hadn’t punctured any vital organs.
Herbert Hoover and his wife were giants of mining engineering.
Herbert Hoover made a fortune as a mining engineer before entering politics during World War I. The 31st president, who got his start consulting on mining projects in Australia and China, had earned a geology degree as part of Stanford University’s first graduating class in 1895. He was one of the few presidents with scientific training, and contemporaries called him the “Great Engineer.” But Hoover’s most enduring scientific contribution came about in collaboration with his wife, Lou Henry Hoover, whom he met when they were both studying at Stanford.
Lou was the first woman to graduate from Stanford with a geology degree. When gender discrimination prevented her from finding work as a field geologist, she pivoted to writing history, learning languages and assisting with her husband’s mining engineering business.
In the early 1900s, the Hoovers, who were then living in London, learned that no one had yet published an English translation of De Re Metallica, a seminal 16th-century mining text. The couple drew on their shared geology background, Hoover’s mining expertise and Lou’s Latin fluency to produce “no mere translation,” said engineering expert John Lienhard in a 1988 episode of the radio program “The Engines of Our Ingenuity.” Their 1912 book, produced over a period of five years, represented “the first comprehensive history of mining that’d ever been written,” Lienhard said. “The Hoovers’ work stands today as the classic in the history of mining.”
Jimmy Carter was a pioneering nuclear engineer and Renaissance man.
Carter, who died in 2024 at 100, was arguably one of the presidents with the most formidable science chops. As Jonathan Alter, author of His Very Best: Jimmy Carter, a Life, says, the 39th president was the “closest to a Renaissance man of any president since Thomas Jefferson.”
Carter graduated from the U.S. Naval Academy in 1946 and quickly gained a reputation in the submarine service as an ace engineer. Selected as a member of the Navy’s nuclear submarine program, Carter and his crewmembers sought to “put a nuclear power plant on a submarine” before civilian authorities could do so on land, says Alter. “He was one of the first nuclear engineers,” certainly in the military, the author adds.
When a nuclear reactor melted down in Ontario, Canada, in 1952, Carter was “one of the few people in the world who had clearance to go into a nuclear power plant,” as he later told CNN. “There were 23 of us, and I was in charge” of the cleanup crew, the president recalled.
Alter notes that Carter wrote 30 books on a “stunning array of topics.” His interests ranged from poetry to carpentry to fishing. He was also a lifelong farmer, resigning from the Navy in 1953 to take over the family peanut farm after his father’s death and greatly expanding the enterprise.
“Saturday Night Live” parodied Carter’s versatility in a 1977 sketch called “Ask President Carter.” Dan Aykroyd, as Carter, answered callers’ questions on any and all topics. He talked a young man down from a harrowing LSD trip, advising him to stay calm, take some vitamin B complex and listen to the Allman Brothers. “So spot on,” says Alter of the sketch.
Some politicians think they’re the smartest person in the room. With Carter, Alter argues, he really did “know what he’s talking about.”

Hundreds of Tourists Flock to This Instagram-Famous Italian Church Every Day. Locals Are Pushing Back Against Visitors Who Seek the Perfect Photo ‘at All Costs’
Beginning in May, travelers visiting Santa Maddalena in the Dolomite Mountains will need to navigate road barriers and parking fees
Nestled in a lush valley in northern Italy, against the backdrop of the Dolomite Mountains, the small village church of Santa Maddalena is the picture of alpine beauty. Up to 600 tourists daily flock to the site, with many posting photos of the historic church on social media. Now, amid an uptick in intrusive behavior by visitors, the roughly 2,500 residents of Funes, the municipality that houses the church, say they’ve finally had enough.
“They want that photo at all costs,” Roswitha Moret Niederwolfsgruber, the local council chief for social welfare, tells the London Times’ James Imam. “They have no respect, walking into people’s gardens and leaving their cars where they want. … We are not living anymore.”
Funes (also known as Villnöss) is a predominantly German-speaking municipality near the Austrian border, in the heart of the UNESCO-listed Dolomites. Before social media introduced the valley’s scenery to a wider audience, Funes was primarily frequented by hikers and outdoor enthusiasts. In recent years, however, a surge in tourism has resulted in “traffic jams, trespassing and a rise in littering,” per the Times.
Did you know? Venice’s day-tripper tax
- In April 2024, Venice became the first city in the world to charge visitors an entrance fee. Introduced in response to overtourism, the measure targets travelers who don’t plan to stay in the Italian city overnight.
- The fee, which ranges from €5 to €10, returned during peak tourist season last year and will take effect on set days in 2026, too.
To curb the flow of visitors to the area, municipal officials plan to install barriers on the narrow road leading to the church, whose structure dates to the late 15th century. Between mid-May and November, car access will be restricted to residents and tourists spending at least one night in the area.
Day-trippers will still be able to visit Santa Maddalena, but they must park in designated areas and walk upward of 30 minutes to reach the church. When those parking lots fill up, which is likely during peak tourist season, vehicles will be instructed to park further down the valley, CNN’s Barbie Latza Nadeau reports. The parking fee, currently €4, will also rise, although officials haven’t yet decided by how much.
“I’m not even saying that tourists are a nuisance,” Peter Pernthaler, the municipality’s mayor, tells CNN. “But a lot of them come, and we have to manage them.”
Officials maintain that these regulations are not intended to halt tourism entirely, but rather to discourage so-called hit-and-run tourists, who stop to snap a photo of the church before moving on, rarely contributing to the local economy by staying in hotels and visiting restaurants.
“They arrive in coaches in the morning,” Carlo Zanella, the president of a local alpine hiking association, tells the Times. “They’re at Cortina by the afternoon and Venice by the evening. They go to Florence and Rome from there, visiting Italy in a week.”
Tensions between locals and tourists have been building in Funes for decades. Though it’s difficult to pinpoint exactly when Santa Maddalena began transforming into a viral sensation, multiple news outlets trace its popularity to 2005, when a Chinese cell phone carrier reportedly printed a photo of the church on its SIM cards.
This isn’t the first time that residents of the Dolomites have objected to mass tourism. Last summer, as roughly 8,000 people a day flocked to the Instagram-famous Seceda mountain, local farmers set up a turnstile on the hiking trail, charging visitors €5 each.
“Ours was a cry for help,” Georg Rabanser, one of the farmers, told the regional La Usc di Ladins newspaper in July 2025, as CNN reported at the time. “We expected a call from the provincial authorities. But nothing.”
The farmers’ protest called attention to the depth of the desperation felt by locals. Whether the changes instituted at Santa Maddalena will address such concerns remains to be seen.
“We need order, both for those who live here and for those who want to arrive, take the classic photo and leave,” Pernthaler tells Martina Capovin of the Il Dolomiti newspaper, per a translation by CNN.
